1â†’# Project Guidelines
     2â†’
     3â†’This file contains the core guidelines for working with code in this repository.
     4â†’AI assistants (Cursor, Claude, Devin, etc.) should refer to this file for context.
     5â†’
     6â†’# Project Overview
     7â†’
     8â†’This project implements an AI codegen agent system with various components for handling API interactions, core logic, and specific agent implementations. The system is built primarily in Python with some TypeScript components.
     9â†’
    10â†’Refer to `agent/architecture.puml` for a visual representation of the system architecture.
    11â†’
    12â†’# Project Structure
    13â†’
    14â†’- `agent` - Contains the main codegen agent code
    15â†’  - `api` - IO layer for the agent
    16â†’    - `agent_server` - API of the agent server
    17â†’      - `models.py` - Models for the agent server consistent with agent_api.tsp
    18â†’      - `agent_api.tsp` - Server type specification for the agent server
    19â†’      - `async_server.py` - Agent server implementation
    20â†’      - `async_agent_session.py` - DEPRECATED: Use trpc_agent/agent_session.py instead
    21â†’    - `cli` - CLI entrypoint (Note: Interacted via test clients, not a dedicated CLI app)
    22â†’  - `core` - Core framework logic (base classes, state machine, etc.)
    23â†’  - `trpc_agent` - Agent for fullstack code generation (new agents follow this pattern)
    24â†’  - `llm` - LLM wrappers
    25â†’  - `stash_bot` - DEPRECATED: Use trpc_agent implementation instead
    26â†’  - `log.py` - Global logging and tracing
    27â†’
    28â†’# Development Workflow
    29â†’
    30â†’Commands should typically be run from the `./agent` directory:
    31â†’
    32â†’- **Run all tests**: `uv run pytest -v .`
    33â†’- **Lint code**: `uv run ruff check` 
    34â†’- **Format code**: `uv run ruff format`
    35â†’- **Run tests in isolated env**: `docker build --target test -t agent-test:latest . && docker run --rm agent-test:latest`
    36â†’- **Build Docker image**: `docker build -t agent:latest .`
    37â†’- **Run Docker container**: `docker run --rm -p 8000:8000 agent:latest`
    38â†’
    39â†’# Lessons
    40â†’
    41â†’## User Specified Lessons
    42â†’- Using `anyio` instead of `asyncio` for async operations is preferred in this codebase
    43â†’- Always activate the Python virtual environment before installing packages
    44â†’- Never use mocks in tests unless explicitly required
    45â†’
    46â†’## Cursor Learned
    47â†’
    48â†’Track learnings and work progress here.
    49â†’
    50â†’### SSE Message Handling Enhancement (Latest)
    51â†’
    52â†’**Problem Solved**: Fixed JSON double-encoding issue in SSE events where content was being JSON-encoded twice, resulting in escaped JSON strings like `{\"status\":\"idle\",\"content\":\"[{\\\"role\\\"...}]\"...}`.
    53â†’
    54â†’**Solution Implemented**:
    55â†’1. **Model Changes**: Updated `AgentMessage` to use structured `messages` field (`List[ExternalContentBlock]`) instead of string `content` field
    56â†’2. **Backward Compatibility**: Kept deprecated `content` field for legacy clients  
    57â†’3. **Agent Session**: Modified `send_event()` to populate both fields - structured messages for new clients, JSON string for legacy
    58â†’4. **Interactive Client**: Enhanced `print_event()` function to:
    59â†’   - Use new structured `messages` field when available
    60â†’   - Fall back to deprecated `content` field for backward compatibility
    61â†’   - Display timestamps with messages in format `[HH:MM:SS] message content`
    62â†’   - Handle multi-line content properly with indentation
    63â†’
    64â†’**New Interactive Commands Added**:
    65â†’- `/messages` - Show detailed message history with timestamps, event metadata, and structured formatting
    66â†’- `/last` - Show latest messages from most recent event for quick review
    67â†’
    68â†’**Technical Details**:
    69â†’- `ExternalContentBlock` contains: `content: str`, `timestamp: datetime`, `role: Literal["assistant"]`  
    70â†’- Messages are displayed with subtle timestamp formatting: `[90m[HH:MM:SS][0m content`
    71â†’- Event status (idle/running) and kind (StageResult/ReviewResult/etc) shown with color coding
    72â†’- Graceful handling of legacy JSON content for backward compatibility
    73â†’
    74â†’This eliminates the double-JSON-encoding issue while providing a better user experience with structured, timestamped messages.
    75â†’
    76â†’**Architectural Improvement**: Moved user-facing message formatting logic from `llm/common.py` to `api/agent_server/models.py` via `format_internal_message_for_display()` function, centralizing SSE-related user interface logic
    77â†’
    78â†’**User-Friendly Tool Reporting**:
    79â†’- Tool uses now display with emoji icons and descriptive names instead of technical format
    80â†’- Context extraction shows relevant information (file paths, commands, descriptions) without JSON dumps
    81â†’- Tool results show completion status with appropriate success/error indicators
    82â†’- Before: `[Tool Use: start_fsm] Input: {"app_description": "..."}`
    83â†’- After: `ðŸš€ Starting application development | Building: A simple application that displays...`
    84â†’
    85â†’This eliminates the double-JSON-encoding issue while providing a better user experience with structured, timestamped messages.
    86â†’
    87â†’# Code Style Guidelines
    88â†’
    89â†’## Python
    90â†’
    91â†’### Key Libraries and Dependencies
    92â†’
    93â†’- `anyio` - Preferred async library
    94â†’- `pytest` - Testing framework
    95â†’- `ruff` - Linting and formatting
    96â†’- `uv` - Package management tool
    97â†’
    98â†’### Code Organization
    99â†’
   100â†’#### File Structure
   101â†’- Keep modules focused on a single responsibility
   102â†’- Group related functions/classes within a module
   103â†’- Use `__init__.py` to expose public interfaces
   104â†’
   105â†’### Formatting and Structure
   106â†’
   107â†’### Imports
   108â†’- **Order**: Standard library imports â†’ Third-party library imports â†’ Local/project imports
   109â†’- **Example**:
   110â†’  ```python
   111â†’  import json
   112â†’  import os
   113â†’  from typing import Dict, List, Optional
   114â†’  
   115â†’  import anyio
   116â†’  import pytest
   117â†’  
   118â†’  from agent.core import BaseClass
   119â†’  from agent.log import get_logger
   120â†’  ```
   121â†’
   122â†’### Language Features
   123â†’
   124â†’### Async Code
   125â†’- **Preferred Library**: Use `anyio` rather than `asyncio`
   126â†’- **Context Managers**: Use async context managers for resource management
   127â†’- **Task Groups**: Group related async operations when possible
   128â†’  ```python
   129â†’  async with anyio.create_task_group() as tg:
   130â†’      tg.start_soon(task_1)
   131â†’      tg.start_soon(task_2)
   132â†’  ```
   133â†’
   134â†’### Type Annotations
   135â†’- Annotate all function parameters and return values
   136â†’- Use `Optional[Type]` or `Type | None` for parameters that can be None (prefer `Type | None`)
   137â†’- Use union types with the pipe operator: `str | None`
   138â†’- Use `TypedDict` for dictionary structures
   139â†’- **Example**:
   140â†’  ```python
   141â†’  from typing import TypedDict, Any
   142â†’  
   143â†’  class Result(TypedDict):
   144â†’      status: str
   145â†’      data: Any
   146â†’      
   147â†’  def process_request(data: Dict[str, Any], timeout: float | None = None) -> Result:
   148â†’      """
   149â†’      Process the incoming request data.
   150â†’      
   151â†’      Args:
   152â†’          data: The request data to process
   153â†’          timeout: Optional timeout in seconds
   154â†’          
   155â†’      Returns:
   156â†’          Result object containing processed data
   157â†’      """
   158â†’      # ... implementation ...
   159â†’      return {"status": "success", "data": {}}
   160â†’  ```
   161â†’
   162â†’### Error Handling and Logging
   163â†’- **Exception Types**: Use specific exception types rather than generic `Exception`. Avoid `except:` without specifying types.
   164â†’- **Custom Exceptions**: Create custom exceptions for domain-specific errors.
   165â†’- **Logging**: Always log exceptions with context using `logger.exception("message")` from `agent.log`.
   166â†’- **Example**:
   167â†’  ```python
   168â†’  from agent.log import get_logger
   169â†’  logger = get_logger(__name__)
   170â†’  
   171â†’  class InvalidDataError(ValueError):
   172â†’      pass
   173â†’  
   174â†’  async def process_data(input_data):
   175â†’      # ... processing ...
   176â†’      if not valid:
   177â†’          raise InvalidDataError("Input data failed validation")
   178â†’      return processed_data
   179â†’  
   180â†’  async def handle_request(input_data):
   181â†’      try:
   182â†’          result = await process_data(input_data)
   183â†’      except InvalidDataError as e:
   184â†’          logger.exception("Invalid data format received")
   185â†’          # Re-raise or handle specific error
   186â†’          raise
   187â†’      except Exception as e:
   188â†’          logger.exception("An unexpected error occurred during processing")
   189â†’          # Handle generic error
   190â†’          raise
   191â†’  ```
   192â†’
   193â†’### Testing
   194â†’- **Framework**: Use `pytest`
   195â†’- **Structure**: 
   196â†’    - Use descriptive test names starting with `test_`.
   197â†’    - Group tests by functionality.
   198â†’    - Use fixtures for common test setups.
   199â†’- **Mocks**: Avoid mocks unless absolutely necessary.
   200â†’- **Example**:
   201â†’  ```python
   202â†’  import pytest
   203â†’  from your_module import process_request # Assuming process_request is defined elsewhere
   204â†’  
   205â†’  @pytest.fixture
   206â†’  def sample_data():
   207â†’      return {"key": "value"}
   208â†’  
   209â†’  def test_process_request_with_valid_data(sample_data):
   210â†’      result = process_request(sample_data)
   211â†’      assert result["status"] == "success"
   212â†’  ```
   213â†’
   214â†’### Common Pitfalls
   215â†’- Avoid global state; use dependency injection.
   216â†’- Be careful with default mutable arguments (e.g., `def func(arg=[]): ...`). Use `arg: list | None = None` and `if arg is None: arg = []` instead.
   217â†’- Always close resources explicitly or use context managers.
   218â†’
   219â†’## TypeScript
   220â†’
   221â†’### Key Libraries and Dependencies
   222â†’
   223â†’- `zod` - Schema validation
   224â†’- `trpc` - API framework (Note: Primarily used for potential future frontend/backend interactions, not core agent logic)
   225â†’
   226â†’### Code Organization
   227â†’
   228â†’#### File Structure
   229â†’- Use a modular approach with clear separation of concerns.
   230â†’- Group related functionality in directories.
   231â†’- Naming pattern: 
   232â†’  - React components: `ComponentName.tsx` (If applicable)
   233â†’  - Utility files: `utility-name.ts`
   234â†’  - Type definitions: `types.ts` or within the module.
   235â†’
   236â†’#### Import Order
   237â†’1. React and framework imports (If applicable)
   238â†’2. Third-party libraries (`zod`, `trpc`, etc.)
   239â†’3. Local components and utilities
   240â†’4. Types and interfaces
   241â†’5. Styles and assets (If applicable)
   242â†’- **Example**:
   243â†’  ```typescript
   244â†’  // import React, { useState, useEffect } from 'react'; // If using React
   245â†’  
   246â†’  import { z } from 'zod';
   247â†’  // import { trpc } from 'trpc'; // If using tRPC client
   248â†’  
   249â†’  // import { Button } from '../components/Button'; // If using React components
   250â†’  import { formatData } from '../utils/formatter';
   251â†’  
   252â†’  import type { User, UserPreferences } from '../types';
   253â†’  
   254â†’  // import styles from './styles.module.css'; // If using CSS Modules
   255â†’  ```
   256â†’
   257â†’### Types
   258â†’- **Best Practices**: 
   259â†’    - Use explicit interfaces over type aliases for objects.
   260â†’    - Use Zod schemas for runtime validation, especially for API boundaries.
   261â†’    - Export types from a central location or alongside their usage.
   262â†’    - Use generics for reusable components and functions.
   263â†’- **Example**:
   264â†’  ```typescript
   265â†’  import { z } from 'zod';
   266â†’  
   267â†’  // Define Zod schema for runtime validation
   268â†’  export const userPreferencesSchema = z.object({
   269â†’    theme: z.enum(['light', 'dark']),
   270â†’    notifications: z.boolean(),
   271â†’  });
   272â†’  
   273â†’  // Define interface using inferred type from Zod
   274â†’  export type UserPreferences = z.infer<typeof userPreferencesSchema>;
   275â†’  
   276â†’  // Define main interface
   277â†’  export interface User {
   278â†’    id: string;
   279â†’    name: string;
   280â†’    email: string;
   281â†’    preferences?: UserPreferences;
   282â†’  }
   283â†’  
   284â†’  // Define Zod schema for User
   285â†’  export const userSchema = z.object({
   286â†’    id: z.string().uuid(),
   287â†’    name: z.string().min(1),
   288â†’    email: z.string().email(),
   289â†’    preferences: userPreferencesSchema.optional(),
   290â†’  });
   291â†’  
   292â†’  // Type for function arguments
   293â†’  function updateUser(user: User, updates: Partial<User>): User {
   294â†’    // Zod validation can be added here if needed
   295â†’    // const validatedUpdates = userSchema.partial().parse(updates);
   296â†’    return { ...user, ...updates }; 
   297â†’  }
   298â†’  ```
   299â†’
   300â†’### Variables
   301â†’- Prefer `const` over `let`.
   302â†’
   303â†’### Naming
   304â†’- Variables/Functions: `camelCase`
   305â†’- Types/Interfaces: `PascalCase`
   306â†’
   307â†’### Imports
   308â†’- No renamed imports unless necessary for clarity or collision avoidance.
   309â†’
   310â†’### API Integration (tRPC Example - If Applicable)
   311â†’- **Patterns**: 
   312â†’    - Define router schemas explicitly.
   313â†’    - Use input validation for all procedures.
   314â†’    - Centralize error handling.
   315â†’- **Example**:
   316â†’  ```typescript
   317â†’  import { z } from 'zod';
   318â†’  // Assume setup for router, procedure, TRPCError, and ctx (context) exists
   319â†’  // import { router, procedure, TRPCError } from '../trpc'; 
   320â†’  // import { db } from '../db'; // Example database context
   321â†’  
   322â†’  export const userRouter = router({
   323â†’    getUser: procedure
   324â†’      .input(z.object({ id: z.string() }))
   325â†’      .query(async ({ input, ctx }) => {
   326â†’        try {
   327â†’          // Replace with actual data fetching logic
   328â†’          // return await ctx.db.user.findUnique({ where: { id: input.id } });
   329â†’          return { id: input.id, name: 'Dummy User' }; // Example return
   330â†’        } catch (error) {
   331â†’          console.error("Failed to fetch user:", error); // Use proper logging
   332â†’          throw new TRPCError({
   333â†’            code: 'INTERNAL_SERVER_ERROR',
   334â†’            message: 'Failed to fetch user',
   335â†’            // cause: error, // Optional: include original error
   336â†’          });
   337â†’        }
   338â†’      }),
   339â†’  });
   340â†’  ```
   341â†’
   342â†’### Component Structure (React Example - If Applicable)
   343â†’- **Patterns**:
   344â†’    - Use functional components with hooks.
   345â†’    - Destructure props at the component level.
   346â†’    - Define prop types using interfaces.
   347â†’    - Use `React.FC` sparingly (prefer explicit return types like `JSX.Element`).
   348â†’- **Example**:
   349â†’  ```typescript
   350â†’  import React from 'react'; // Assuming React is used
   351â†’  // import styles from './styles.module.css'; // Example CSS Modules
   352â†’
   353â†’  interface ButtonProps {
   354â†’    label: string;
   355â†’    onClick: () => void;
   356â†’    disabled?: boolean;
   357â†’  }
   358â†’  
   359â†’  function Button({ label, onClick, disabled = false }: ButtonProps): JSX.Element {
   360â†’    return (
   361â†’      <button 
   362â†’        onClick={onClick}
   363â†’        disabled={disabled}
   364â†’        // className={styles.button} // Example styling
   365â†’      >
   366â†’        {label}
   367â†’      </button>
   368â†’    );
   369â†’  }
   370â†’  ```
   371â†’
   372â†’### State Management (React Example - If Applicable)
   373â†’- **Best Practices**: 
   374â†’    - Use React hooks (`useState`, `useReducer`) for local state.
   375â†’    - Consider context (`useContext`) for simple shared state.
   376â†’    - Use dedicated state management libraries (like Zustand, Redux) for complex global state.
   377â†’    - Keep state normalized.
   378â†’- **Example using `useReducer`**:
   379â†’  ```typescript
   380â†’  // Assume reducer, initialState are defined
   381â†’  // const [state, dispatch] = useReducer(reducer, initialState);
   382â†’  
   383â†’  // // Later in component
   384â†’  // dispatch({ type: 'UPDATE_USER', payload: { id, data } });
   385â†’  ```
   386â†’
   387â†’### Error Handling
   388â†’- **Patterns**: 
   389â†’    - Use `try/catch` blocks for async operations.
   390â†’    - Create custom error classes for domain-specific errors.
   391â†’    - Use error boundaries for component errors (in React).
   392â†’- **Example**:
   393â†’  ```typescript
   394â†’  class ApiError extends Error {
   395â†’    constructor(message: string) {
   396â†’      super(message);
   397â†’      this.name = 'ApiError';
   398â†’    }
   399â†’  }
   400â†’  
   401â†’  async function fetchData() {
   402â†’    // ... fetch logic that might throw ...
   403â†’  }
   404â†’  
   405â†’  async function process() {
   406â†’    let data;
   407â†’    let error = null;
   408â†’    try {
   409â†’      data = await fetchData();
   410â†’    } catch (err) {
   411â†’      if (err instanceof ApiError) {
   412â†’        error = `API Error: ${err.message}`;
   413â†’      } else if (err instanceof Error) {
   414â†’        error = `An unexpected error occurred: ${err.message}`;
   415â†’        console.error(err); // Use proper logging
   416â†’      } else {
   417â†’        error = 'An unknown error occurred';
   418â†’        console.error(err);
   419â†’      }
   420â†’    }
   421â†’    // ... handle data or error ...
   422â†’  }
   423â†’  ```
   424â†’
   425â†’### Testing (Example using Jest/React Testing Library - If Applicable)
   426â†’- **Patterns**:
   427â†’    - Use Jest and React Testing Library for UI components.
   428â†’    - Test component behavior, not implementation details.
   429â†’    - Mock API calls and external dependencies.
   430â†’    - Use `data-testid` attributes for reliable test selectors.
   431â†’- **Example**:
   432â†’  ```typescript
   433â†’  // import { render, screen, fireEvent } from '@testing-library/react';
   434â†’  // import { UserProfile } from './UserProfile'; // Example component
   435â†’  
   436â†’  // const mockUser = { id: '1', name: 'Test User', email: 'test@example.com' };
   437â†’  
   438â†’  // test('displays user information correctly', () => {
   439â†’  //   render(<UserProfile user={mockUser} />);
   440â†’  
   441â†’  //   expect(screen.getByText(mockUser.name)).toBeInTheDocument();
   442â†’  //   expect(screen.getByText(mockUser.email)).toBeInTheDocument();
   443â†’  
   444â†’  //   // Example interaction
   445â†’  //   // fireEvent.click(screen.getByRole('button', { name: /Edit Profile/i }));
   446â†’  //   // expect(screen.getByTestId('edit-form')).toBeInTheDocument();
   447â†’  // });
   448â†’  ```
   449â†’
   450â†’### Common Pitfalls
   451â†’- Avoid `any` type; use `unknown` if type is truly unknown and perform checks.
   452â†’- Be careful with nullish values; use optional chaining (`?.`) and nullish coalescing (`??`).
   453â†’- Avoid type assertions (`as Type`) when possible; prefer type guards or narrowing.
   454â†’- Don't use `==`; always use `===` for strict equality checks.
   455â†’- Remember that empty objects (`{}`) are truthy.
   456â†’
   457â†’# LLM Model Configuration (2025)
   458â†’
   459â†’The agent system supports multiple LLM providers with category-based selection for optimal performance.
   460â†’
   461â†’## Model Categories
   462â†’
   463â†’The system uses three main categories:
   464â†’- **FAST_TEXT**: Quick tasks (name generation, commit messages, simple text processing)
   465â†’- **BEST_CODEGEN**: Complex code generation and reasoning tasks
   466â†’- **VISION**: Image analysis and UI understanding
   467â†’
   468â†’## Current Defaults (Updated Jan 2025)
   469â†’
   470â†’```python
   471â†’from llm.utils import get_fast_text_client, get_best_codegen_client, get_vision_client
   472â†’from llm.models_config import ModelCategory
   473â†’
   474â†’# Recommended usage - these use current defaults
   475â†’fast_client = get_fast_text_client()        # Uses Ministral 3B
   476â†’codegen_client = get_best_codegen_client()  # Uses Codestral 22B  
   477â†’vision_client = get_vision_client()         # Uses LLaMA 3.2 Vision
   478â†’```
   479â†’
   480â†’## Latest Model Recommendations
   481â†’
   482â†’Based on [recent performance benchmarks](https://medium.com/@rameshkannanyt0078/the-best-ollama-models-for-developers-and-programmers-1662dae514a7) and [Ollama model availability](https://ollama.com/), here are the current best options:
   483â†’
   484â†’### For Local Development (Ollama)
   485â†’- **Fast Tasks**: `ministral` (3B) - Fastest Mistral model
   486â†’- **Code Generation**: `codestral` (22B) - Specialized for code
   487â†’- **Vision Tasks**: `llama3.2-vision` - Latest Meta vision model
   488â†’- **Advanced Coding**: `qwen3-coder` (7B) - Best coding performance
   489â†’- **Large Tasks**: `qwen3` (30B) - Advanced reasoning with thinking mode
   490â†’
   491â†’### For Cloud APIs
   492â†’- **Fast Tasks**: `gemini-flash-lite` (Google)
   493â†’- **Code Generation**: `sonnet` (Anthropic Claude)
   494â†’- **Vision Tasks**: `gemini-flash` (Google)
   495â†’
   496â†’## Environment Configuration
   497â†’
   498â†’Create a `.env` file to override defaults:
   499â†’
   500â†’```bash
   501â†’# Recommended: Latest non-Chinese models (2025)
   502â†’LLM_FAST_MODEL=ministral           # Mistral 3B
   503â†’LLM_CODEGEN_MODEL=codestral        # Mistral 22B 
   504â†’LLM_VISION_MODEL=llama3.2-vision   # Meta Vision
   505â†’
   506â†’# Alternative: All-American models
   507â†’# LLM_FAST_MODEL=phi4              # Microsoft 14B
   508â†’# LLM_CODEGEN_MODEL=granite-code   # IBM 20B
   509â†’# LLM_VISION_MODEL=llama3.2-vision # Meta Vision
   510â†’
   511â†’# For highest performance (includes Chinese models)
   512â†’# LLM_CODEGEN_MODEL=qwen3-coder    # Best for coding
   513â†’# LLM_VISION_MODEL=qwen3           # Advanced vision + thinking
   514â†’
   515â†’# API Keys (if using cloud models)
   516â†’ANTHROPIC_API_KEY=your_key_here
   517â†’GEMINI_API_KEY=your_key_here
   518â†’OLLAMA_HOST=http://localhost:11434
   519â†’```
   520â†’
   521â†’## Migration from Old Function Names
   522â†’
   523â†’The system now provides both legacy and new function names:
   524â†’
   525â†’```python
   526â†’# Legacy (still works)
   527â†’from llm.utils import get_fast_llm_client, get_codegen_llm_client, get_vision_llm_client
   528â†’
   529â†’# New recommended names (same functionality)
   530â†’from llm.utils import get_fast_text_client, get_best_codegen_client, get_vision_client
   531â†’
   532â†’# Or use the category-based approach
   533â†’from llm.utils import get_llm_client_by_category
   534â†’from llm.models_config import ModelCategory
   535â†’
   536â†’client = get_llm_client_by_category(ModelCategory.BEST_CODEGEN)
   537â†’```
   538â†’
   539â†’## Setting Up Ollama
   540â†’
   541â†’To use local models, install and start Ollama:
   542â†’
   543â†’```bash
   544â†’# Install Ollama
   545â†’curl -fsSL https://ollama.ai/install.sh | sh
   546â†’
   547â†’# Pull recommended models
   548â†’ollama pull ministral      # Fast tasks
   549â†’ollama pull codestral:22b  # Code generation
   550â†’ollama pull llama3.2-vision # Vision tasks
   551â†’
   552â†’# Optional: Advanced models
   553â†’ollama pull qwen3-coder:7b  # Excellent coding
   554â†’ollama pull qwen3:30b       # Advanced reasoning
   555â†’```
   556â†’
   557â†’Then set `OLLAMA_HOST=http://localhost:11434` in your `.env` file.
   558â†’
   559â†’## Model Performance Notes
   560â†’
   561â†’- **Ministral (3B)**: Fastest for simple tasks, low memory usage
   562â†’- **Codestral (22B)**: Best balance of performance and speed for coding
   563â†’- **Qwen3-Coder (7B)**: Highest coding performance per parameter
   564â†’- **LLaMA 3.2 Vision**: Most reliable for image analysis
   565â†’- **Qwen3 (30B)**: Advanced reasoning with "thinking mode" capability
   566â†’
   567â†’Choose models based on your hardware capabilities and performance requirements.
   568â†’
   569â†’## Test LLM Provider Flexibility (Jan 2025)
   570â†’
   571â†’**Problem Solved**: Tests were hardcoded to only run when `GEMINI_API_KEY` was set, making it impossible to run tests with Ollama or other LLM providers.
   572â†’
   573â†’**Solution Implemented**:
   574â†’1. **Centralized Provider Detection**: Created `tests/test_utils.py` with `is_llm_provider_available()` function that checks for any configured LLM provider:
   575â†’   - Cloud providers: `GEMINI_API_KEY`, `ANTHROPIC_API_KEY`, `AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY`/`PREFER_BEDROCK`
   576â†’   - Local providers: `PREFER_OLLAMA` 
   577â†’   - Explicit model overrides: `LLM_FAST_MODEL`, `LLM_CODEGEN_MODEL`, `LLM_VISION_MODEL`
   578â†’
   579â†’2. **Updated Test Conditions**: Replaced hardcoded `@pytest.mark.skipif(os.getenv("GEMINI_API_KEY") is None)` with flexible `@pytest.mark.skipif(requires_llm_provider())` in:
   580â†’   - `tests/test_e2e.py::test_e2e_generation` 
   581â†’   - `tests/test_cached_llm.py` (4 tests)
   582â†’
   583â†’3. **Provider-Agnostic Test Names**: Renamed tests from `test_gemini*` to `test_llm_*` to reflect their provider independence
   584â†’
   585â†’**Usage Examples**:
   586â†’```bash
   587â†’# Run tests with Ollama
   588â†’PREFER_OLLAMA=1 uv run pytest tests/test_e2e.py
   589â†’
   590â†’# Run tests with Gemini  
   591â†’GEMINI_API_KEY=your_key uv run pytest tests/test_e2e.py
   592â†’
   593â†’# Run tests with Anthropic
   594â†’ANTHROPIC_API_KEY=your_key uv run pytest tests/test_e2e.py
   595â†’
   596â†’# Tests are skipped when no provider is configured
   597â†’uv run pytest tests/test_e2e.py  # SKIPPED
   598â†’```
   599â†’
   600â†’This enables the test suite to work with any configured LLM provider, supporting both cloud and local development workflows.
   601â†’
   602â†’**Critical Fix**: Updated `tests/test_utils.py` to load `.env` files at import time, ensuring environment variables are available when `@pytest.mark.skipif` conditions are evaluated during test collection phase.
   603â†’
   604â†’

# Project Guidelines

This file contains the core guidelines for working with code in this repository.
AI assistants (Cursor, Claude, Devin, etc.) should refer to this file for context.

# Project Overview

This project implements an AI codegen agent system with various components for handling API interactions, core logic, and specific agent implementations. The system is built primarily in Python with some TypeScript components.

Refer to `agent/architecture.puml` for a visual representation of the system architecture.

# Project Structure

- `agent` - Contains the main codegen agent code
  - `api` - IO layer for the agent
    - `agent_server` - API of the agent server
      - `models.py` - Models for the agent server consistent with agent_api.tsp
      - `agent_api.tsp` - Server type specification for the agent server
      - `async_server.py` - Agent server implementation
      - `async_agent_session.py` - DEPRECATED: Use trpc_agent/agent_session.py instead
    - `cli` - CLI entrypoint (Note: Interacted via test clients, not a dedicated CLI app)
  - `core` - Core framework logic (base classes, state machine, etc.)
  - `trpc_agent` - Agent for fullstack code generation (new agents follow this pattern)
  - `llm` - LLM wrappers
  - `stash_bot` - DEPRECATED: Use trpc_agent implementation instead
  - `log.py` - Global logging and tracing

# Development Workflow

Commands should typically be run from the `./agent` directory:

- **Run all tests**: `uv run pytest -v .`
- **Lint code**: `uv run ruff check` 
- **Format code**: `uv run ruff format`
- **Run tests in isolated env**: `docker build --target test -t agent-test:latest . && docker run --rm agent-test:latest`
- **Build Docker image**: `docker build -t agent:latest .`
- **Run Docker container**: `docker run --rm -p 8000:8000 agent:latest`

# Lessons

## User Specified Lessons
- Using `anyio` instead of `asyncio` for async operations is preferred in this codebase
- Always activate the Python virtual environment before installing packages
- Never use mocks in tests unless explicitly required

## Cursor Learned

Track learnings and work progress here.

### SSE Message Handling Enhancement (Latest)

**Problem Solved**: Fixed JSON double-encoding issue in SSE events where content was being JSON-encoded twice, resulting in escaped JSON strings like `{\"status\":\"idle\",\"content\":\"[{\\\"role\\\"...}]\"...}`.

**Solution Implemented**:
1. **Model Changes**: Updated `AgentMessage` to use structured `messages` field (`List[ExternalContentBlock]`) instead of string `content` field
2. **Backward Compatibility**: Kept deprecated `content` field for legacy clients  
3. **Agent Session**: Modified `send_event()` to populate both fields - structured messages for new clients, JSON string for legacy
4. **Interactive Client**: Enhanced `print_event()` function to:
   - Use new structured `messages` field when available
   - Fall back to deprecated `content` field for backward compatibility
   - Display timestamps with messages in format `[HH:MM:SS] message content`
   - Handle multi-line content properly with indentation

**New Interactive Commands Added**:
- `/messages` - Show detailed message history with timestamps, event metadata, and structured formatting
- `/last` - Show latest messages from most recent event for quick review

**Technical Details**:
- `ExternalContentBlock` contains: `content: str`, `timestamp: datetime`, `role: Literal["assistant"]`  
- Messages are displayed with subtle timestamp formatting: `[90m[HH:MM:SS][0m content`
- Event status (idle/running) and kind (StageResult/ReviewResult/etc) shown with color coding
- Graceful handling of legacy JSON content for backward compatibility

This eliminates the double-JSON-encoding issue while providing a better user experience with structured, timestamped messages.

**Architectural Improvement**: Moved user-facing message formatting logic from `llm/common.py` to `api/agent_server/models.py` via `format_internal_message_for_display()` function, centralizing SSE-related user interface logic

**User-Friendly Tool Reporting**:
- Tool uses now display with emoji icons and descriptive names instead of technical format
- Context extraction shows relevant information (file paths, commands, descriptions) without JSON dumps
- Tool results show completion status with appropriate success/error indicators
- Before: `[Tool Use: start_fsm] Input: {"app_description": "..."}`
- After: `ðŸš€ Starting application development | Building: A simple application that displays...`

This eliminates the double-JSON-encoding issue while providing a better user experience with structured, timestamped messages.

# Code Style Guidelines

## Python

### Key Libraries and Dependencies

- `anyio` - Preferred async library
- `pytest` - Testing framework
- `ruff` - Linting and formatting
- `uv` - Package management tool

### Code Organization

#### File Structure
- Keep modules focused on a single responsibility
- Group related functions/classes within a module
- Use `__init__.py` to expose public interfaces

### Formatting and Structure

### Imports
- **Order**: Standard library imports â†’ Third-party library imports â†’ Local/project imports
- **Example**:
  ```python
  import json
  import os
  from typing import Dict, List, Optional
  
  import anyio
  import pytest
  
  from agent.core import BaseClass
  from agent.log import get_logger
  ```

### Language Features

### Async Code
- **Preferred Library**: Use `anyio` rather than `asyncio`
- **Context Managers**: Use async context managers for resource management
- **Task Groups**: Group related async operations when possible
  ```python
  async with anyio.create_task_group() as tg:
      tg.start_soon(task_1)
      tg.start_soon(task_2)
  ```

### Type Annotations
- Annotate all function parameters and return values
- Use `Optional[Type]` or `Type | None` for parameters that can be None (prefer `Type | None`)
- Use union types with the pipe operator: `str | None`
- Use `TypedDict` for dictionary structures
- **Example**:
  ```python
  from typing import TypedDict, Any
  
  class Result(TypedDict):
      status: str
      data: Any
      
  def process_request(data: Dict[str, Any], timeout: float | None = None) -> Result:
      """
      Process the incoming request data.
      
      Args:
          data: The request data to process
          timeout: Optional timeout in seconds
          
      Returns:
          Result object containing processed data
      """
      # ... implementation ...
      return {"status": "success", "data": {}}
  ```

### Error Handling and Logging
- **Exception Types**: Use specific exception types rather than generic `Exception`. Avoid `except:` without specifying types.
- **Custom Exceptions**: Create custom exceptions for domain-specific errors.
- **Logging**: Always log exceptions with context using `logger.exception("message")` from `agent.log`.
- **Example**:
  ```python
  from agent.log import get_logger
  logger = get_logger(__name__)
  
  class InvalidDataError(ValueError):
      pass
  
  async def process_data(input_data):
      # ... processing ...
      if not valid:
          raise InvalidDataError("Input data failed validation")
      return processed_data
  
  async def handle_request(input_data):
      try:
          result = await process_data(input_data)
      except InvalidDataError as e:
          logger.exception("Invalid data format received")
          # Re-raise or handle specific error
          raise
      except Exception as e:
          logger.exception("An unexpected error occurred during processing")
          # Handle generic error
          raise
  ```

### Testing
- **Framework**: Use `pytest`
- **Structure**: 
    - Use descriptive test names starting with `test_`.
    - Group tests by functionality.
    - Use fixtures for common test setups.
- **Mocks**: Avoid mocks unless absolutely necessary.
- **Example**:
  ```python
  import pytest
  from your_module import process_request # Assuming process_request is defined elsewhere
  
  @pytest.fixture
  def sample_data():
      return {"key": "value"}
  
  def test_process_request_with_valid_data(sample_data):
      result = process_request(sample_data)
      assert result["status"] == "success"
  ```

### Common Pitfalls
- Avoid global state; use dependency injection.
- Be careful with default mutable arguments (e.g., `def func(arg=[]): ...`). Use `arg: list | None = None` and `if arg is None: arg = []` instead.
- Always close resources explicitly or use context managers.

## TypeScript

### Key Libraries and Dependencies

- `zod` - Schema validation
- `trpc` - API framework (Note: Primarily used for potential future frontend/backend interactions, not core agent logic)

### Code Organization

#### File Structure
- Use a modular approach with clear separation of concerns.
- Group related functionality in directories.
- Naming pattern: 
  - React components: `ComponentName.tsx` (If applicable)
  - Utility files: `utility-name.ts`
  - Type definitions: `types.ts` or within the module.

#### Import Order
1. React and framework imports (If applicable)
2. Third-party libraries (`zod`, `trpc`, etc.)
3. Local components and utilities
4. Types and interfaces
5. Styles and assets (If applicable)
- **Example**:
  ```typescript
  // import React, { useState, useEffect } from 'react'; // If using React
  
  import { z } from 'zod';
  // import { trpc } from 'trpc'; // If using tRPC client
  
  // import { Button } from '../components/Button'; // If using React components
  import { formatData } from '../utils/formatter';
  
  import type { User, UserPreferences } from '../types';
  
  // import styles from './styles.module.css'; // If using CSS Modules
  ```

### Types
- **Best Practices**: 
    - Use explicit interfaces over type aliases for objects.
    - Use Zod schemas for runtime validation, especially for API boundaries.
    - Export types from a central location or alongside their usage.
    - Use generics for reusable components and functions.
- **Example**:
  ```typescript
  import { z } from 'zod';
  
  // Define Zod schema for runtime validation
  export const userPreferencesSchema = z.object({
    theme: z.enum(['light', 'dark']),
    notifications: z.boolean(),
  });
  
  // Define interface using inferred type from Zod
  export type UserPreferences = z.infer<typeof userPreferencesSchema>;
  
  // Define main interface
  export interface User {
    id: string;
    name: string;
    email: string;
    preferences?: UserPreferences;
  }
  
  // Define Zod schema for User
  export const userSchema = z.object({
    id: z.string().uuid(),
    name: z.string().min(1),
    email: z.string().email(),
    preferences: userPreferencesSchema.optional(),
  });
  
  // Type for function arguments
  function updateUser(user: User, updates: Partial<User>): User {
    // Zod validation can be added here if needed
    // const validatedUpdates = userSchema.partial().parse(updates);
    return { ...user, ...updates }; 
  }
  ```

### Variables
- Prefer `const` over `let`.

### Naming
- Variables/Functions: `camelCase`
- Types/Interfaces: `PascalCase`

### Imports
- No renamed imports unless necessary for clarity or collision avoidance.

### API Integration (tRPC Example - If Applicable)
- **Patterns**: 
    - Define router schemas explicitly.
    - Use input validation for all procedures.
    - Centralize error handling.
- **Example**:
  ```typescript
  import { z } from 'zod';
  // Assume setup for router, procedure, TRPCError, and ctx (context) exists
  // import { router, procedure, TRPCError } from '../trpc'; 
  // import { db } from '../db'; // Example database context
  
  export const userRouter = router({
    getUser: procedure
      .input(z.object({ id: z.string() }))
      .query(async ({ input, ctx }) => {
        try {
          // Replace with actual data fetching logic
          // return await ctx.db.user.findUnique({ where: { id: input.id } });
          return { id: input.id, name: 'Dummy User' }; // Example return
        } catch (error) {
          console.error("Failed to fetch user:", error); // Use proper logging
          throw new TRPCError({
            code: 'INTERNAL_SERVER_ERROR',
            message: 'Failed to fetch user',
            // cause: error, // Optional: include original error
          });
        }
      }),
  });
  ```

### Component Structure (React Example - If Applicable)
- **Patterns**:
    - Use functional components with hooks.
    - Destructure props at the component level.
    - Define prop types using interfaces.
    - Use `React.FC` sparingly (prefer explicit return types like `JSX.Element`).
- **Example**:
  ```typescript
  import React from 'react'; // Assuming React is used
  // import styles from './styles.module.css'; // Example CSS Modules

  interface ButtonProps {
    label: string;
    onClick: () => void;
    disabled?: boolean;
  }
  
  function Button({ label, onClick, disabled = false }: ButtonProps): JSX.Element {
    return (
      <button 
        onClick={onClick}
        disabled={disabled}
        // className={styles.button} // Example styling
      >
        {label}
      </button>
    );
  }
  ```

### State Management (React Example - If Applicable)
- **Best Practices**: 
    - Use React hooks (`useState`, `useReducer`) for local state.
    - Consider context (`useContext`) for simple shared state.
    - Use dedicated state management libraries (like Zustand, Redux) for complex global state.
    - Keep state normalized.
- **Example using `useReducer`**:
  ```typescript
  // Assume reducer, initialState are defined
  // const [state, dispatch] = useReducer(reducer, initialState);
  
  // // Later in component
  // dispatch({ type: 'UPDATE_USER', payload: { id, data } });
  ```

### Error Handling
- **Patterns**: 
    - Use `try/catch` blocks for async operations.
    - Create custom error classes for domain-specific errors.
    - Use error boundaries for component errors (in React).
- **Example**:
  ```typescript
  class ApiError extends Error {
    constructor(message: string) {
      super(message);
      this.name = 'ApiError';
    }
  }
  
  async function fetchData() {
    // ... fetch logic that might throw ...
  }
  
  async function process() {
    let data;
    let error = null;
    try {
      data = await fetchData();
    } catch (err) {
      if (err instanceof ApiError) {
        error = `API Error: ${err.message}`;
      } else if (err instanceof Error) {
        error = `An unexpected error occurred: ${err.message}`;
        console.error(err); // Use proper logging
      } else {
        error = 'An unknown error occurred';
        console.error(err);
      }
    }
    // ... handle data or error ...
  }
  ```

### Testing (Example using Jest/React Testing Library - If Applicable)
- **Patterns**:
    - Use Jest and React Testing Library for UI components.
    - Test component behavior, not implementation details.
    - Mock API calls and external dependencies.
    - Use `data-testid` attributes for reliable test selectors.
- **Example**:
  ```typescript
  // import { render, screen, fireEvent } from '@testing-library/react';
  // import { UserProfile } from './UserProfile'; // Example component
  
  // const mockUser = { id: '1', name: 'Test User', email: 'test@example.com' };
  
  // test('displays user information correctly', () => {
  //   render(<UserProfile user={mockUser} />);
  
  //   expect(screen.getByText(mockUser.name)).toBeInTheDocument();
  //   expect(screen.getByText(mockUser.email)).toBeInTheDocument();
  
  //   // Example interaction
  //   // fireEvent.click(screen.getByRole('button', { name: /Edit Profile/i }));
  //   // expect(screen.getByTestId('edit-form')).toBeInTheDocument();
  // });
  ```

### Common Pitfalls
- Avoid `any` type; use `unknown` if type is truly unknown and perform checks.
- Be careful with nullish values; use optional chaining (`?.`) and nullish coalescing (`??`).
- Avoid type assertions (`as Type`) when possible; prefer type guards or narrowing.
- Don't use `==`; always use `===` for strict equality checks.
- Remember that empty objects (`{}`) are truthy.

# LLM Model Configuration (2025)

The agent system supports multiple LLM providers with category-based selection for optimal performance.

## Model Categories

The system uses three main categories:
- **FAST_TEXT**: Quick tasks (name generation, commit messages, simple text processing)
- **BEST_CODEGEN**: Complex code generation and reasoning tasks
- **VISION**: Image analysis and UI understanding

## Current Defaults (Updated Jan 2025)

```python
from llm.utils import get_fast_text_client, get_best_codegen_client, get_vision_client
from llm.models_config import ModelCategory

# Recommended usage - these use current defaults
fast_client = get_fast_text_client()        # Uses Ministral 3B
codegen_client = get_best_codegen_client()  # Uses Codestral 22B  
vision_client = get_vision_client()         # Uses LLaMA 3.2 Vision
```

## Latest Model Recommendations

Based on [recent performance benchmarks](https://medium.com/@rameshkannanyt0078/the-best-ollama-models-for-developers-and-programmers-1662dae514a7) and [Ollama model availability](https://ollama.com/), here are the current best options:

### For Local Development (Ollama)
- **Fast Tasks**: `ministral` (3B) - Fastest Mistral model
- **Code Generation**: `codestral` (22B) - Specialized for code
- **Vision Tasks**: `llama3.2-vision` - Latest Meta vision model
- **Advanced Coding**: `qwen3-coder` (7B) - Best coding performance
- **Large Tasks**: `qwen3` (30B) - Advanced reasoning with thinking mode

### For Cloud APIs
- **Fast Tasks**: `gemini-flash-lite` (Google)
- **Code Generation**: `sonnet` (Anthropic Claude)
- **Vision Tasks**: `gemini-flash` (Google)

## Environment Configuration

Create a `.env` file to override defaults:

```bash
# Recommended: Latest non-Chinese models (2025)
LLM_FAST_MODEL=ministral           # Mistral 3B
LLM_CODEGEN_MODEL=codestral        # Mistral 22B 
LLM_VISION_MODEL=llama3.2-vision   # Meta Vision

# Alternative: All-American models
# LLM_FAST_MODEL=phi4              # Microsoft 14B
# LLM_CODEGEN_MODEL=granite-code   # IBM 20B
# LLM_VISION_MODEL=llama3.2-vision # Meta Vision

# For highest performance (includes Chinese models)
# LLM_CODEGEN_MODEL=qwen3-coder    # Best for coding
# LLM_VISION_MODEL=qwen3           # Advanced vision + thinking

# API Keys (if using cloud models)
ANTHROPIC_API_KEY=your_key_here
GEMINI_API_KEY=your_key_here
OLLAMA_HOST=http://localhost:11434
```

## Migration from Old Function Names

The system now provides both legacy and new function names:

```python
# Legacy (still works)
from llm.utils import get_fast_llm_client, get_codegen_llm_client, get_vision_llm_client

# New recommended names (same functionality)
from llm.utils import get_fast_text_client, get_best_codegen_client, get_vision_client

# Or use the category-based approach
from llm.utils import get_llm_client_by_category
from llm.models_config import ModelCategory

client = get_llm_client_by_category(ModelCategory.BEST_CODEGEN)
```

## Setting Up Ollama

To use local models, install and start Ollama:

```bash
# Install Ollama
curl -fsSL https://ollama.ai/install.sh | sh

# Pull recommended models
ollama pull ministral      # Fast tasks
ollama pull codestral:22b  # Code generation
ollama pull llama3.2-vision # Vision tasks

# Optional: Advanced models
ollama pull qwen3-coder:7b  # Excellent coding
ollama pull qwen3:30b       # Advanced reasoning
```

Then set `OLLAMA_HOST=http://localhost:11434` in your `.env` file.

## Model Performance Notes

- **Ministral (3B)**: Fastest for simple tasks, low memory usage
- **Codestral (22B)**: Best balance of performance and speed for coding
- **Qwen3-Coder (7B)**: Highest coding performance per parameter
- **LLaMA 3.2 Vision**: Most reliable for image analysis
- **Qwen3 (30B)**: Advanced reasoning with "thinking mode" capability

Choose models based on your hardware capabilities and performance requirements.

## Test LLM Provider Flexibility (Jan 2025)

**Problem Solved**: Tests were hardcoded to only run when `GEMINI_API_KEY` was set, making it impossible to run tests with Ollama or other LLM providers.

**Solution Implemented**:
1. **Centralized Provider Detection**: Created `tests/test_utils.py` with `is_llm_provider_available()` function that checks for any configured LLM provider:
   - Cloud providers: `GEMINI_API_KEY`, `ANTHROPIC_API_KEY`, `AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY`/`PREFER_BEDROCK`
   - Local providers: `PREFER_OLLAMA` 
   - Explicit model overrides: `LLM_FAST_MODEL`, `LLM_CODEGEN_MODEL`, `LLM_VISION_MODEL`

2. **Updated Test Conditions**: Replaced hardcoded `@pytest.mark.skipif(os.getenv("GEMINI_API_KEY") is None)` with flexible `@pytest.mark.skipif(requires_llm_provider())` in:
   - `tests/test_e2e.py::test_e2e_generation` 
   - `tests/test_cached_llm.py` (4 tests)

3. **Provider-Agnostic Test Names**: Renamed tests from `test_gemini*` to `test_llm_*` to reflect their provider independence

**Usage Examples**:
```bash
# Run tests with Ollama
PREFER_OLLAMA=1 uv run pytest tests/test_e2e.py

# Run tests with Gemini  
GEMINI_API_KEY=your_key uv run pytest tests/test_e2e.py

# Run tests with Anthropic

# Tests are skipped when no provider is configured
uv run pytest tests/test_e2e.py  # SKIPPED
```

This enables the test suite to work with any configured LLM provider, supporting both cloud and local development workflows.

**Critical Fix**: Updated `tests/test_utils.py` to load `.env` files at import time, ensuring environment variables are available when `@pytest.mark.skipif` conditions are evaluated during test collection phase.

# PR Creation Command

Create a pull request with proper formatting and description.

Title:
- The title needs to follow semantic versioning.
- The title needs to be a single line.
- The title needs to be a short description of the changes.
- The title needs to be a single line.

## Usage
```bash
gh pr create --title "{{TITLE}}" --body "$(cat <<'EOF'
## Description

This PR aims to (replace with a short description of the changes).

**FEATURES**
- [bullet point]

**FIXES**
- [bullet point]

**BREAKING CHANGES**
- [bullet point]

## Test Plan

EOF
)"
```

## Description
This command creates a GitHub pull request using the `gh` CLI tool with:
- A descriptive title
- A formatted body using a heredoc for proper multiline handling
- Template placeholder for consistent PR descriptions

If $ARGUMENTS is provided, follow the instructions in the arguments.

input.content:
#!/bin/bash

# Setup 5 git worktrees for parallel development
# Each worktree gets its own branch for isolated work

set -e

SCRIPT_DIR="$(cd "$(dirname "${BASH_SOURCE[0]}")" && pwd)"
AGENT_DIR="$(dirname "$SCRIPT_DIR")"
WORKTREES_DIR="$(dirname "$AGENT_DIR")/agent-worktrees"

echo "Setting up 5 worktrees for parallel development..."
echo "Main repo: $AGENT_DIR"
echo "Worktrees dir: $WORKTREES_DIR"

# Create worktrees directory
mkdir -p "$WORKTREES_DIR"

# Function to setup a single worktree
setup_worktree() {
    local agent_num=$1
    local worktree_dir="$WORKTREES_DIR/agent-$agent_num"
    local branch_name="experiment/agent-$agent_num"
    
    echo "Setting up agent-$agent_num..."
    
    # Remove existing worktree if it exists
    if [ -d "$worktree_dir" ]; then
        echo "  Removing existing worktree: $worktree_dir"
        cd "$AGENT_DIR"
        git worktree remove "$worktree_dir" --force 2>/dev/null || true
        git branch -D "$branch_name" 2>/dev/null || true
    fi
    
    # Create new branch and worktree
    cd "$AGENT_DIR"
    echo "  Creating branch: $branch_name"
    git checkout -b "$branch_name" 2>/dev/null || git checkout "$branch_name"
    git checkout main  # Switch back to main
    
    echo "  Creating worktree: $worktree_dir"
    git worktree add "$worktree_dir" "$branch_name"
    
    echo "  âœ“ agent-$agent_num ready at $worktree_dir"
}

# Setup all 5 worktrees
for i in {1..5}; do
    setup_worktree $i
done

echo ""
echo "ðŸŽ‰ All worktrees created successfully!"
echo ""
echo "Worktrees:"
cd "$AGENT_DIR"
git worktree list

echo ""
echo "You can now run: @worktree-run \"your prompt here\""

#!/bin/bash

# Run the same prompt on 5 Claude agents in parallel using tmux
# Each agent works in its own worktree for isolated development

set -e

SCRIPT_DIR="$(cd "$(dirname "${BASH_SOURCE[0]}")" && pwd)"
AGENT_DIR="$(dirname "$SCRIPT_DIR")"
WORKTREES_DIR="$(dirname "$AGENT_DIR")/agent-worktrees"
SESSION_NAME="parallel-agents"
LOG_DIR="$AGENT_DIR/logs/parallel-run-$(date +%Y%m%d-%H%M%S)"

# Check if prompt was provided
if [ -z "$1" ]; then
    echo "âŒ Error: Please provide a prompt"
    echo "Usage: $0 \"your prompt here\""
    exit 1
fi

PROMPT="$1"

echo "ðŸš€ Starting 5 parallel Claude agents..."
echo "Prompt: $PROMPT"
echo "Session: $SESSION_NAME"
echo "Logs: $LOG_DIR"

# Create log directory
mkdir -p "$LOG_DIR"

# Check if worktrees exist
if [ ! -d "$WORKTREES_DIR" ]; then
    echo "âŒ Error: Worktrees not found. Run @worktree-init first."
    exit 1
fi

# Kill existing session if it exists
tmux kill-session -t "$SESSION_NAME" 2>/dev/null || true

# Create new tmux session with 5 panes
echo "Creating tmux session with 5 panes..."

# Create session with first pane
tmux new-session -d -s "$SESSION_NAME" -c "$WORKTREES_DIR/agent-1"

# Split into 5 panes
tmux split-window -h -t "$SESSION_NAME" -c "$WORKTREES_DIR/agent-2"
tmux split-window -v -t "$SESSION_NAME:0.0" -c "$WORKTREES_DIR/agent-3"
tmux split-window -v -t "$SESSION_NAME:0.1" -c "$WORKTREES_DIR/agent-4"
tmux split-window -v -t "$SESSION_NAME:0.3" -c "$WORKTREES_DIR/agent-5"

# Balance the panes
tmux select-layout -t "$SESSION_NAME" tiled

# Function to setup a single agent pane
setup_agent_pane() {
    local agent_num=$1
    local pane_id=$((agent_num - 1))
    local worktree_dir="$WORKTREES_DIR/agent-$agent_num"

#!/bin/bash

# Run the same prompt on 5 Claude agents in parallel using tmux
# Each agent works in its own worktree for isolated development

set -e

SCRIPT_DIR="$(cd "$(dirname "${BASH_SOURCE[0]}")" && pwd)"
AGENT_DIR="$(dirname "$SCRIPT_DIR")"
WORKTREES_DIR="$(dirname "$AGENT_DIR")/agent-worktrees"
SESSION_NAME="parallel-agents"
LOG_DIR="$AGENT_DIR/logs/parallel-run-$(date +%Y%m%d-%H%M%S)"

# Check if prompt was provided
if [ -z "$1" ]; then
    echo "âŒ Error: Please provide a prompt"
    echo "Usage: $0 \"your prompt here\""
    exit 1
fi

PROMPT="$1"

echo "ðŸš€ Starting 5 parallel Claude agents..."
echo "Prompt: $PROMPT"
echo "Session: $SESSION_NAME"
echo "Logs: $LOG_DIR"

# Create log directory
mkdir -p "$LOG_DIR"

# Check if worktrees exist
if [ ! -d "$WORKTREES_DIR" ]; then
    echo "âŒ Error: Worktrees not found. Run @worktree-init first."
    exit 1
fi

# Kill existing session if it exists
tmux kill-session -t "$SESSION_NAME" 2>/dev/null || true

# Create new tmux session with 5 panes
echo "Creating tmux session with 5 panes..."

# Create session with first pane
tmux new-session -d -s "$SESSION_NAME" -c "$WORKTREES_DIR/agent-1"

# Split into 5 panes
tmux split-window -h -t "$SESSION_NAME" -c "$WORKTREES_DIR/agent-2"
tmux split-window -v -t "$SESSION_NAME:0.0" -c "$WORKTREES_DIR/agent-3"
tmux split-window -v -t "$SESSION_NAME:0.1" -c "$WORKTREES_DIR/agent-4"
tmux split-window -v -t "$SESSION_NAME:0.3" -c "$WORKTREES_DIR/agent-5"

# Balance the panes
tmux select-layout -t "$SESSION_NAME" tiled

# Function to setup a single agent pane
setup_agent_pane() {
    local agent_num=$1
    local pane_id=$((agent_num - 1))
    local worktree_dir="$WORKTREES_DIR/agent-$agent_num"

#!/bin/bash

# Compare results across all 5 worktrees
# Shows git diff, file changes, and generates a summary report

set -e

SCRIPT_DIR="$(cd "$(dirname "${BASH_SOURCE[0]}")" && pwd)"
AGENT_DIR="$(dirname "$SCRIPT_DIR")"
WORKTREES_DIR="$(dirname "$AGENT_DIR")/agent-worktrees"
REPORT_DIR="$AGENT_DIR/reports/comparison-$(date +%Y%m%d-%H%M%S)"

echo "ðŸ” Comparing results across 5 worktrees..."
echo "Report will be saved to: $REPORT_DIR"

# Create report directory
mkdir -p "$REPORT_DIR"

# Check if worktrees exist
if [ ! -d "$WORKTREES_DIR" ]; then
    echo "âŒ Error: Worktrees not found. Run @worktree-init first."
    exit 1
fi

# Function to analyze a single worktree
analyze_worktree() {
    local agent_num=$1
    local worktree_dir="$WORKTREES_DIR/agent-$agent_num"
    local output_file="$REPORT_DIR/agent-$agent_num-analysis.txt"
    
    if [ ! -d "$worktree_dir" ]; then
        echo "âŒ Warning: agent-$agent_num worktree not found"
        return
    fi
    
    echo "ðŸ“Š Analyzing agent-$agent_num..."
    
    cd "$worktree_dir"
    
    {
        echo "=============================================="
        echo "AGENT $agent_num ANALYSIS"
        echo "=============================================="
        echo "Directory: $worktree_dir"
        echo "Branch: $(git branch --show-current)"
        echo "Timestamp: $(date)"
        echo ""
        
        echo "--- GIT STATUS ---"
        git status --porcelain || echo "No git changes"
        echo ""
        
        echo "--- CHANGED FILES ---"
        git diff --name-only HEAD 2>/dev/null || echo "No changes"
        echo ""
        
        echo "--- COMMIT HISTORY ---"
        git log --oneline -10 2>/dev/null || echo "No commits"
        echo ""
        
        echo "--- DETAILED DIFF ---"
        git diff HEAD 2>/dev/null || echo "No diff"
        echo ""
        
        echo "--- FILE TREE (new/modified files) ---"
        find . -name ".git" -prune -o -type f -newer ../agent-1/.git/refs/heads/experiment/agent-1 -print 2>/dev/null | head -20 || echo "No new files detected"
        echo ""
        
    } > "$output_file"
    
    echo "  âœ“ Analysis saved to: $output_file"
}

# Analyze all worktrees
for i in {1..5}; do
    analyze_worktree $i
done

# Generate summary report
echo ""
echo "ðŸ“‹ Generating summary report..."

{
    echo "=============================================="
    echo "PARALLEL AGENTS COMPARISON REPORT"
    echo "=============================================="
    echo "Generated: $(date)"
    echo "Worktrees: $WORKTREES_DIR"
    echo ""
    
    echo "--- SUMMARY ---"
    for i in {1..5}; do
        worktree_dir="$WORKTREES_DIR/agent-$i"
        if [ -d "$worktree_dir" ]; then
            cd "$worktree_dir"
            changed_files=$(git diff --name-only HEAD 2>/dev/null | wc -l | tr -d ' ')
            commits=$(git rev-list --count HEAD ^main 2>/dev/null || echo "0")
            echo "Agent $i: $changed_files changed files, $commits commits"
        else
            echo "Agent $i: Not found"
        fi
    done
    echo ""
    
    echo "--- UNIQUE APPROACHES ---"
    echo "Files changed by each agent:"
    for i in {1..5}; do
        worktree_dir="$WORKTREES_DIR/agent-$i"
        if [ -d "$worktree_dir" ]; then
            cd "$worktree_dir"
            echo "Agent $i:"
            git diff --name-only HEAD 2>/dev/null | sed 's/^/  /' || echo "  No changes"
        fi
    done
    echo ""
    
    echo "--- COMMON PATTERNS ---"
    echo "Files modified by multiple agents:"
    
    # Find files that appear in multiple agents' changes
    all_files="/tmp/all_changed_files_$$"
    > "$all_files"
    
    for i in {1..5}; do
        worktree_dir="$WORKTREES_DIR/agent-$i"
        if [ -d "$worktree_dir" ]; then
            cd "$worktree_dir"
            git diff --name-only HEAD 2>/dev/null >> "$all_files"
        fi
    done
    
    if [ -s "$all_files" ]; then
        sort "$all_files" | uniq -c | sort -nr | head -10
    else
        echo "No common files found"
    fi
    
    rm -f "$all_files"
    echo ""
    
    echo "--- RECOMMENDATIONS ---"
    echo "â€¢ Review the detailed analysis files for each agent"
    echo "â€¢ Compare specific implementations in files changed by multiple agents"
    echo "â€¢ Consider merging the best approaches from each agent"
    echo "â€¢ Look for patterns in how different agents approached the same problem"
    echo ""
    
} > "$REPORT_DIR/summary-report.txt"

echo ""
echo "ðŸŽ‰ Comparison complete!"
echo ""
echo "ðŸ“ Report files:"
echo "  Summary: $REPORT_DIR/summary-report.txt"
for i in {1..5}; do
    if [ -f "$REPORT_DIR/agent-$i-analysis.txt" ]; then
        echo "  Agent $i: $REPORT_DIR/agent-$i-analysis.txt"
    fi
done

echo ""
echo "ðŸ“– View summary report:"
echo "  cat $REPORT_DIR/summary-report.txt"

#!/bin/bash

# Clean up all 5 worktrees and their branches
# Removes worktrees, deletes branches, and cleans up logs

set -e

SCRIPT_DIR="$(cd "$(dirname "${BASH_SOURCE[0]}")" && pwd)"
AGENT_DIR="$(dirname "$SCRIPT_DIR")"
WORKTREES_DIR="$(dirname "$AGENT_DIR")/agent-worktrees"
SESSION_NAME="parallel-agents"

echo "ðŸ§¹ Cleaning up parallel agent worktrees..."

# Kill tmux session if it exists
if tmux has-session -t "$SESSION_NAME" 2>/dev/null; then
    echo "Killing tmux session: $SESSION_NAME"
    tmux kill-session -t "$SESSION_NAME"
fi

# Function to clean up a single worktree
cleanup_worktree() {
    local agent_num=$1
    local worktree_dir="$WORKTREES_DIR/agent-$agent_num"
    local branch_name="experiment/agent-$agent_num"
    
    echo "Cleaning up agent-$agent_num..."
    
    # Remove worktree if it exists
    if [ -d "$worktree_dir" ]; then
        echo "  Removing worktree: $worktree_dir"
        cd "$AGENT_DIR"
        git worktree remove "$worktree_dir" --force 2>/dev/null || true
    fi
    
    # Delete branch if it exists
    cd "$AGENT_DIR"
    if git show-ref --verify --quiet "refs/heads/$branch_name"; then
        echo "  Deleting branch: $branch_name"
        git branch -D "$branch_name" 2>/dev/null || true
    fi
    
    echo "  âœ“ agent-$agent_num cleaned up"
}

# Clean up all 5 worktrees
for i in {1..5}; do
    cleanup_worktree $i
done

# Remove worktrees directory if it's empty
if [ -d "$WORKTREES_DIR" ] && [ -z "$(ls -A "$WORKTREES_DIR")" ]; then
    echo "Removing empty worktrees directory: $WORKTREES_DIR"
    rmdir "$WORKTREES_DIR"
fi

# Optional: Clean up logs and reports (with confirmation)
echo ""
read -p "ðŸ—‘ï¸  Also clean up logs and reports? [y/N]: " -n 1 -r
echo
if [[ $REPLY =~ ^[Yy]$ ]]; then
    if [ -d "$AGENT_DIR/logs" ]; then
        echo "Removing logs directory: $AGENT_DIR/logs"
        rm -rf "$AGENT_DIR/logs"
    fi
    
    if [ -d "$AGENT_DIR/reports" ]; then
        echo "Removing reports directory: $AGENT_DIR/reports"
        rm -rf "$AGENT_DIR/reports"
    fi
fi

echo ""
echo "ðŸŽ‰ Cleanup complete!"
echo ""
echo "Current git worktrees:"
cd "$AGENT_DIR"
git worktree list

echo ""
echo "To start over, run: @worktree-init"

#!/bin/bash

# Show status of all 5 worktrees
# Displays git status, branch info, and recent activity

set -e

SCRIPT_DIR="$(cd "$(dirname "${BASH_SOURCE[0]}")" && pwd)"
AGENT_DIR="$(dirname "$SCRIPT_DIR")"
WORKTREES_DIR="$(dirname "$AGENT_DIR")/agent-worktrees"
SESSION_NAME="parallel-agents"

echo "ðŸ“Š Worktree Status Report"
echo "========================="

# Check if worktrees directory exists
if [ ! -d "$WORKTREES_DIR" ]; then
    echo "âŒ No worktrees found. Run @worktree-init to create them."
    exit 0
fi

# Check tmux session status
echo ""
echo "ðŸ–¥ï¸  Tmux Session:"
if tmux has-session -t "$SESSION_NAME" 2>/dev/null; then
    echo "  âœ… Session '$SESSION_NAME' is running"
    echo "  ðŸ“º Attach with: tmux attach -t $SESSION_NAME"
else
    echo "  â­• No active session '$SESSION_NAME'"
    echo "  ðŸš€ Start with: @worktree-run \"your prompt\""
fi

echo ""
echo "ðŸŒ² Git Worktrees:"
cd "$AGENT_DIR"
git worktree list

echo ""
echo "ðŸ“ Detailed Status:"

# Function to show status for a single worktree
show_worktree_status() {
    local agent_num=$1
    local worktree_dir="$WORKTREES_DIR/agent-$agent_num"
    local branch_name="experiment/agent-$agent_num"
    
    echo ""
    echo "--- Agent $agent_num ---"
    
    if [ ! -d "$worktree_dir" ]; then
        echo "âŒ Worktree not found: $worktree_dir"
        return
    fi
    
    cd "$worktree_dir"
    
    # Basic info
    echo "ðŸ“ Location: $worktree_dir"
    echo "ðŸŒ¿ Branch: $(git branch --show-current)"
    
    # Git status
    local status_output=$(git status --porcelain 2>/dev/null)
    if [ -z "$status_output" ]; then
        echo "âœ… Clean working tree"
    else
        echo "ðŸ”„ Working tree changes:"
        echo "$status_output" | head -5 | sed 's/^/   /'
        local count=$(echo "$status_output" | wc -l | tr -d ' ')
        if [ "$count" -gt 5 ]; then
            echo "   ... and $((count - 5)) more files"
        fi
    fi
    
    # Recent commits
    local commit_count=$(git rev-list --count HEAD ^main 2>/dev/null || echo "0")
    if [ "$commit_count" -gt 0 ]; then
        echo "ðŸ“ Commits ahead of main: $commit_count"
        echo "   Latest: $(git log --oneline -1 2>/dev/null || echo 'No commits')"
    else
        echo "ðŸ“ No commits ahead of main"
    fi
    
    # Last modified
    local last_modified=$(find . -name ".git" -prune -o -type f -print0 2>/dev/null | xargs -0 stat -f "%m %N" 2>/dev/null | sort -nr | head -1 | cut -d' ' -f2- || echo "")
    if [ -n "$last_modified" ]; then
        local mod_time=$(stat -f "%Sm" "$last_modified" 2>/dev/null || echo "unknown")
        echo "â° Last modified: $(basename "$last_modified") at $mod_time"
    fi
}

# Show status for all worktrees
for i in {1..5}; do
    show_worktree_status $i
done

echo ""
echo "ðŸ“Š Summary:"
echo "==========="

# Count active worktrees
active_count=0
for i in {1..5}; do
    if [ -d "$WORKTREES_DIR/agent-$i" ]; then
        active_count=$((active_count + 1))
    fi
done

echo "ðŸ  Active worktrees: $active_count/5"

# Count worktrees with changes
changed_count=0
for i in {1..5}; do
    worktree_dir="$WORKTREES_DIR/agent-$i"
    if [ -d "$worktree_dir" ]; then
        cd "$worktree_dir"
        if [ -n "$(git status --porcelain 2>/dev/null)" ]; then
            changed_count=$((changed_count + 1))
        fi
    fi
done

echo "ðŸ”„ Worktrees with changes: $changed_count/$active_count"

# Count commits
total_commits=0
for i in {1..5}; do
    worktree_dir="$WORKTREES_DIR/agent-$i"
    if [ -d "$worktree_dir" ]; then
        cd "$worktree_dir"
        commits=$(git rev-list --count HEAD ^main 2>/dev/null || echo "0")
        total_commits=$((total_commits + commits))
    fi
done

echo "ðŸ“ Total commits across all agents: $total_commits"

echo ""
echo "âš¡ Quick Actions:"
echo "  @worktree-run \"prompt\"  - Run prompt on all agents"
echo "  @worktree-compare        - Compare agent results"
echo "  @worktree-clean          - Clean up everything"

#!/bin/bash

# Show status of all 5 worktrees
# Displays git status, branch info, and recent activity

set -e

SCRIPT_DIR="$(cd "$(dirname "${BASH_SOURCE[0]}")" && pwd)"
AGENT_DIR="$(dirname "$SCRIPT_DIR")"
WORKTREES_DIR="$(dirname "$AGENT_DIR")/agent-worktrees"
SESSION_NAME="parallel-agents"

echo "ðŸ“Š Worktree Status Report"
echo "========================="

# Check if worktrees directory exists
if [ ! -d "$WORKTREES_DIR" ]; then
    echo "âŒ No worktrees found. Run @worktree-init to create them."
    exit 0
fi

# Check tmux session status
echo ""
echo "ðŸ–¥ï¸  Tmux Session:"
if tmux has-session -t "$SESSION_NAME" 2>/dev/null; then
    echo "  âœ… Session '$SESSION_NAME' is running"
    echo "  ðŸ“º Attach with: tmux attach -t $SESSION_NAME"
else
    echo "  â­• No active session '$SESSION_NAME'"
    echo "  ðŸš€ Start with: @worktree-run \"your prompt\""
fi

echo ""
echo "ðŸŒ² Git Worktrees:"
cd "$AGENT_DIR"
git worktree list

echo ""
echo "ðŸ“ Detailed Status:"

# Function to show status for a single worktree
show_worktree_status() {
    local agent_num=$1
    local worktree_dir="$WORKTREES_DIR/agent-$agent_num"
    local branch_name="experiment/agent-$agent_num"
    
    echo ""
    echo "--- Agent $agent_num ---"
    
    if [ ! -d "$worktree_dir" ]; then
        echo "âŒ Worktree not found: $worktree_dir"
        return
    fi
    
    cd "$worktree_dir"
    
    # Basic info
    echo "ðŸ“ Location: $worktree_dir"
    echo "ðŸŒ¿ Branch: $(git branch --show-current)"
    
    # Git status
    local status_output=$(git status --porcelain 2>/dev/null)
    if [ -z "$status_output" ]; then
        echo "âœ… Clean working tree"
    else
        echo "ðŸ”„ Working tree changes:"
        echo "$status_output" | head -5 | sed 's/^/   /'
        local count=$(echo "$status_output" | wc -l | tr -d ' ')
        if [ "$count" -gt 5 ]; then
            echo "   ... and $((count - 5)) more files"
        fi
    fi
    
    # Recent commits
    local commit_count=$(git rev-list --count HEAD ^main 2>/dev/null || echo "0")
    if [ "$commit_count" -gt 0 ]; then
        echo "ðŸ“ Commits ahead of main: $commit_count"
        echo "   Latest: $(git log --oneline -1 2>/dev/null || echo 'No commits')"
    else
        echo "ðŸ“ No commits ahead of main"
    fi
    
    # Last modified
    local last_modified=$(find . -name ".git" -prune -o -type f -print0 2>/dev/null | xargs -0 stat -f "%m %N" 2>/dev/null | sort -nr | head -1 | cut -d' ' -f2- || echo "")
    if [ -n "$last_modified" ]; then
        local mod_time=$(stat -f "%Sm" "$last_modified" 2>/dev/null || echo "unknown")
        echo "â° Last modified: $(basename "$last_modified") at $mod_time"
    fi
}

# Show status for all worktrees
for i in {1..5}; do
    show_worktree_status $i
done

echo ""
echo "ðŸ“Š Summary:"
echo "==========="

# Count active worktrees
active_count=0
for i in {1..5}; do
    if [ -d "$WORKTREES_DIR/agent-$i" ]; then
        active_count=$((active_count + 1))
    fi
done

echo "ðŸ  Active worktrees: $active_count/5"

# Count worktrees with changes
changed_count=0
for i in {1..5}; do
    worktree_dir="$WORKTREES_DIR/agent-$i"
    if [ -d "$worktree_dir" ]; then
        cd "$worktree_dir"
        if [ -n "$(git status --porcelain 2>/dev/null)" ]; then
            changed_count=$((changed_count + 1))
        fi
    fi
done

echo "ðŸ”„ Worktrees with changes: $changed_count/$active_count"

# Count commits
total_commits=0
for i in {1..5}; do
    worktree_dir="$WORKTREES_DIR/agent-$i"
    if [ -d "$worktree_dir" ]; then
        cd "$worktree_dir"
        commits=$(git rev-list --count HEAD ^main 2>/dev/null || echo "0")
        total_commits=$((total_commits + commits))
    fi
done

echo "ðŸ“ Total commits across all agents: $total_commits"

echo ""
echo "âš¡ Quick Actions:"
echo "  @worktree-run \"prompt\"  - Run prompt on all agents"
echo "  @worktree-compare        - Compare agent results"
echo "  @worktree-clean          - Clean up everything"
